article.title: Equivalence of restricted Boltzmann machines and tensor network states

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following best describes the difference between how connection weights are represented in an RBM versus a Tensor Network State (TNS)?
choices: RBMs use lines for connection weights, TNS use dots.
RBMs use dots for connection weights, TNS use lines.
RBMs use lines for connection weights, TNS use lines.
RBMs use dots for connection weights, TNS use dots.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the bond dimension (D) of the MPS in Figure 2(c) represent?
choices: The number of visible units in the RBM.
The number of hidden units in the RBM.
The number of connections cut by the corresponding dashed vertical line.
The total number of connections in the RBM.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the optimal mapping of RBM to MPS, what criteria does the set Z (light green ellipse) need to fulfill?
choices: Z contains all hidden units connected to the current visible unit.
Z is the smallest set that makes X and Y conditionally independent.
Z contains an equal number of visible and hidden units.
Z is chosen arbitrarily to minimize the number of connections.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the cyan dots in Figure 7(c-e) represent compared to Figure 7(b)?
choices: Visible units with a bias of 0.
Hidden units with a bias of ùúã.
Visible units with a bias of ùúã.
Hidden units with a bias of 0.
